scenarioDescription:
The GJ 1061 Exoplanetary System


Overview

GJ 1061 is a star with 0.12 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.16 times its radius. It is located 11.98 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 7 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

GJ 1061 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the GJ 1061 system


GJ 1061 b

GJ 1061 b was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2020-03, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.02 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 1061 b is 1.371 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 1061 b is 1.100 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, GJ 1061 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.


GJ 1061 c

GJ 1061 c was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2020-03, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 1061 c is 1.739 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 1061 c is 1.180 that of Earth. At 1.739 Earth masses, GJ 1061 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


GJ 1061 d

GJ 1061 d was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2020-03, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 1061 d is 1.641 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 1061 d is 1.160 that of Earth. At 1.641 Earth masses, GJ 1061 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses. GJ 1061 d orbits within the habitable zone of its parent star and could, potentially, be a habitable planet with stable bodies of liquid water on its surface, like Earth.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system GJ 1061, which contains 3 exoplanets, of which 1 is potentially habitable, and was discovered by the La Silla Observatory.
name: GJ 1061 - System With 3 Exolanets of Which 1 Is Potentially Habitable
